body: Hey, @CarvalhoLeonardo and @arsulegai we made an XO Android example client. Do you want to take a look?
Hey, looks nice!
I'll spin up an image and review it as soon as possible!

> Hey, @CarvalhoLeonardo and @arsulegai we made an XO Android example client. Do you want to take a look?

Awesome, need some time to review
@arsulegai Can you review this?

@peterschwarz We could deploy to staging, but not release, would be one way.

I think that is what I will do. I will work with @rbuysse and @rberg2 today to see if we can deploy this, before I merge it.
I'm not sure I like 'sawtooth-sdk-transaction-processor' as an artifact name, but its probably fine. Otherwise this LGTM.
@CarvalhoLeonardo @arsulegai any opinions on splitting the sdk into three jars?

> @CarvalhoLeonardo @arsulegai any opinions on splitting the sdk into three jars?

   I think it is fine, I did something like this, but I would open space for a 4th module, to handle REST artifacts...

<...>
>     * peg the maven version used in docker files due to a inconsistency between maven 3.5.4 and jdk 8. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53010200/maven-surefire-could-not-find-forkedbooter-class
> <....>

   I would like to suggest bumping the Java version to 11, due to this points:
- Java 8 has many [issues](https://blog.docker.com/2018/04/improved-docker-container-integration-with-java-10/) on virtualization, corrected in java 10.
- Java 8 will start the [EOL cycle](https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/eol-135779.html) next year.
- Java 10/11 are VERY optimized for streams and multithread applications. (and I strongly advocate the use of reactive programming.)
- The changes I've submitted where created using Java 10, so, there's no compatibility issue.
- But, Java 10 it's [already EOLed](https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/eol-135779.html).

My 2 cents.
@arsulegai With regards to including all of the protos for every interface. I think it is fine to do so. I think it allows people to innovate where necessary.
@arsulegai I will make a README.md in a later PR. I don't want to hold this one up.
@arsulegai @CarvalhoLeonardo Can you guys review this?
@CarvalhoLeonardo I used your bitcoinj signing method from your PR. To make a pluggable signer with the NativeSecp256k1Signer, you would implement Context.
I'll keep that in mind, thank you.
Thoughts on the package being "sawtooth.signing" instead of the longer "sawtooth.sdk.client.signing"? If we move this to its own module/jar file, thoughts on the package name due to that?

> Thoughts on the package being "sawtooth.signing" instead of the longer "sawtooth.sdk.client.signing"? If we move this to its own module/jar file, thoughts on the package name due to that?

@vaporos I think if it is its own module/jar, it could be "sawtooth.signing". I expect to do that work sometime soon.

I only did in separate packages because the inner workings on each
scenario (server and client) are slightly different, like I commented above.

I also agree with the shortening of the package names the `sdk` in `sawtooth.sdk.*` seems rather redundant overall. And `sawtooth.signing` definitely feels more appropriate for that package in general.
I missed some lint. I will close until I have that fixed up.
Guys, I got a very extensive delta to commit, how can I help this work, breaking it in smaller chuncks ? Is there a how to, a document, something like that?

I tested that the sdk, intkey, and xo all build using the build scripts (on Mac). Also that `intkey-tp-java` and `xo-tp-java` can start up.

@rbuysse is .pylintrc and .pycodestyle necessary?

@rbuysse should I expect a `Dockerfile-installed` in each repo?
In a subsequent commit can you add a BUILD.md or README.md that tells people how to use the repo. Kinda like the c++ file?
